oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Jimmy Bowen Interview by John Lomax III Side Two
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is an interview of Jimmy Bowen. The interview takes place on 11-18-86.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Jimmy Bowen
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Side Two - (0:18) -- Jimmy Bowen speaks about hiring his secretary and assistant Martha Sharp. Jimmy Bowen describes the joy of building a smaller company from the ground floor up. (0:59) -- Jimmy Bowen speaks about cleaning up artist rosters at Elektra, Warner Brothers, and MCA. (2:08) -- Jimmy Bowen describes flying to Dallas to make the deal with Joe Smith about taking over Elektra. (3:50) -- Jimmy Bowen tells a story about speaking with Hank Williams Jr. about his recent written material ("Family Tradition"). Hank Williams Jr. hated speaking with Jimmy Bowen because he was "from the record company." (7:05) -- Jimmy Bowen speaks about artists cutting albums similar to their live shows. (8:50) -- Jimmy Bowen speaks about leaving Warner Brothers in 1968 because it was a "gentlemen's club." (9:21) -- Jimmy Bowen speaks fondly about working with Irving Azoff. (10:42) -- Jimmy Bowen speaks about the messy transition from Warner Brothers to MCA. (16:10) -- Jimmy Bowen speaks about his professional differences with Warner Brothers. (19:01) - Jimmy Bowen mentions all of the companies he's worked for in Nashville. (19:55) -- Jimmy Bowen discusses working for a publishing company named "American Music." (21:43) -- Jimmy Bowen describes recording Judy Canova. (23:02) -- Jimmy Bowen mentions being hired by Frank Sinatra. (24:08) -- Jimmy Bowen mentions Phil Spector using his office at Reprise Records in California. (24:45) -- Jimmy Bowen mentions the influence of Phil Spector on his producing. (26:10) -- Jimmy Bowen discusses Waylon Jennings working with the Glaser Brothers. (27:44) -- Jimmy Bowen speaks about the future of digital music and tape piracy. (31:44) -- John Lomax asks Jimmy Bowen what he listens to in his spare time from work. Jimmy Bowen explains that it is almost all work-related. (34:44) -- Jimmy Bowen speaks about mastering an Oak Ridge Boys album. (37:48) -- Jimmy Bowen mentions his childhood music lessons.
